Content:
They've been deleting people's messages from telegram that were bringing up this issue/question. Stating that they will be releasing an official statement soon and that "it is not a vulnerability and you will read why in the statement"
"ssl encrypted due to jxbrowser, but 'invalid' request that never was processed by google anyway. the spellcheck is local. please wait for the full official statement that will answer all your questions and again, this was only valid for desktop clients, and only when you restored seed."
Still looks like a terrible idea...

Author: Regnar#6164
Content:
"The spell-check requests that were sent over to Google API were not processed, cached or stored and the requests themselves returned an error (code: 400) as they were flagged as ‚ÄúBad Request‚Äù¬π and weren‚Äôt processed further by Google¬≤" 

That first footnote is a screenshot of the results NOW... I'd like to know if this had in fact been an active API request BEFORE, and at what point it started returning 400 codes? 
The 2nd footnote they cited saying they "weren't process further by Google" is NOT actually sourced, that is their current assumption with no verification from Google. The footnote reads "¬≤ We have asked Google to confirm that bad requests‚Äô text body isn‚Äôt stored on their servers, we will update our statement accordingly."
So they don't actually know if Google logs failed API request information...

Messy

Author: Regnar#6164
Content: I guess it would be good to use the older version (if someone has it) to check to see if it returns a 400 or 200, and if the App actually performs a spell check on a misspelling?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: even if it returns error now and always did, sending privkeys to a server (any server) is not what people are expecting from a local wallet. imagine if they were sending the privkeys to their own server, what is the reaction

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and isnt sending it to a server you dont even control, WORSE than sending it to your own servers??

Author: Regnar#6164
Content: Right

Author: Regnar#6164
Content: I'm definitely in the "That's a bad idea" camp. I'm wondering about their response to the whole thing basically saying it isn't a big deal because it returned 400 codes and Google didn't log these, when we and they don't know if either of those are actually true.

Author: Regnar#6164
Content: They seem to be saying that the app has always returned 400 codes and Google doesn't log these requests, so no one's keys have ever been at risk, trying to remove any liability they may face for bad key management practice, or what might be considered negligence (I'm not a lawyer, I don't know how that would work).

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if they have the usual software license, odds are they are not liable at all
